questions.question: What is the luminescence quantum yield of NCP-1?
What materials were used to synthesize the phosphorescent nanoscale coordination polymers?
questions.answer: The phosphorescent nanoscale coordination polymers were synthesized using the [Ru{5,5â€™-(CO2)2-bpy}(bpy)2] bridging ligand and Zn2+ or Zr4+ connecting points.

questions.question: What was the method used to stabilize the zirconium NCP and what was its purpose?
questions.answer: The zirconium NCP was stabilized with a silica coating to prevent rapid release from the nanoparticles.

questions.question: How was the targeting molecule attached to the silica-coated NCPs?
questions.answer: The targeting molecule was attached to the silica-coated NCPs by functionalizing with poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) and a targeting molecule for in vitro optical imaging of cancer cells.

questions.question: What was the half-life of SiO2@2 particles in 8 mm PBS at 37 8C?
questions.answer: The half-life of SiO2@2 particles in 8 mm PBS at 37 8C was about 3.2 hours.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the in vitro viability assays on H460 human non-small-cell lung cancer cells treated with PEG-SiO2@2 and AA-PEG-SiO2@2?
questions.answer: Treatment of H460 cells with PEG-SiO2@2 and AA-PEG-SiO2@2 did not lead to any appreciable cell death after 24 hours of incubation.

questions.question: What was the purpose of incorporating luminescent molecules into the nanoparticles?
questions.answer: The purpose of incorporating luminescent molecules into the nanoparticles was to create highly luminescent nanoparticles that do not undergo self-quenching, for use as contrast agents in optical imaging.

questions.question: Why were Zr4+ ions considered for synthesizing more stable NCPs in place of Zn2+?
questions.answer: Zr4+ ions were considered for synthesizing more stable NCPs in place of Zn2+ because materials composed of Zr4+ ions and dicarboxylate bridging ligands were shown to be among the most stable coordination polymers synthesized.

questions.question: How did the researchers confirm the presence of the polymer coating on the nanoparticles?
questions.answer: The presence of the polymer coating on the nanoparticles was confirmed through TGA, DLS measurements, and observing a rougher edge around the particles by TEM.

questions.question: What was the effect of the anisamide-targeted particles on the optical imaging contrast efficiency and targeting capacity?
questions.answer: The anisamide-targeted particles exhibited efficient optical imaging contrast and cancer specificity, as demonstrated by enhanced uptake in H460 cells and significant luminescent signal observed in confocal z section images.

questions.question: What was the role of silica coating in the synthesis of NCP-2?
questions.answer: The role of silica coating in the synthesis of NCP-2 was to slow down the release of L dye molecules from the nanoparticles in biologically relevant media.

questions.question: Why was PEG used in the functionalization of SiO2@2 nanoparticles?
questions.answer: PEG was used in the functionalization of SiO2@2 nanoparticles to prevent particle aggregation, increase the dispersibility of nanoparticles, and enhance biocompatibility.

questions.question: True or False: The luminescence quantum yield of NCP-2 is higher than that of NCP-1.
True or False: The zirconium-based NCPs were not stable under the coating conditions.
True or False: The dye loading in NCP-2 was higher than in the zinc NCPs.
True or False: The silica coating on NCP-2 particles did not affect their hydrodynamic diameter.
True or False: The presence of PEG on the nanoparticles did not change their zeta potential.
True or False: The anisamide-targeted particles did not show enhanced uptake in H460 cells compared to non-targeted particles.
True or False: The synthesized nanoparticles were intended for use in magnetic resonance imaging.
True or False: The synthesized nanoparticles dissolve rapidly in water and biologically relevant media.
questions.answer: True for NCP-1, False for silica-coated NCP-2.
